__data__.text: Claude, the youngest of three children, was born to parents Henry (originally from Germany) and Mary (from England) Wilschefski in Maryborough, Queensland, Australia on December 2, 1902. The families of both parents had migrated to Australia in the late 1800s and they got married in 1897.

Henry, Claude's father, passed away in Queensland when Claude was only 11 months old, in 1903. Later, in 1907, Mary, Claude's mother, remarried Francis Martin List, a German-born man. Together, they had five children, with the first one, Norman Andrew List, passing away as an infant. The remaining four children, Alice Holly List, Francis Martin List, Edna Marjorie List, and Irene Maude List, became Claude's half-siblings.

After Henry's death in 1903, Claude's mother, Mary, remarried Francis List in 1907, who became Claude's stepfather. They had five children together, making them Claude's half-siblings. The family relocated to New Zealand between 1915 and 1919, residing in Glen Eden by 1919. Francis and Claude played rugby league together, as Francis was a senior player. Claude began playing rugby league in Queensland at around 10 years old in 1912 and continued in New Zealand after moving there, with the family settling in Auckland.

Following the family's move to New Zealand between 1915 and 1919, they settled in Auckland where Claude, then 18, joined the Kingsland Rovers rugby league team in 1921. His first appearance in the Auckland Star was on June 10, 1921, listed in the third grade side along with another List, possibly his older brother Percy. The Kingsland Rovers won the 3rd grade championship that year.

After winning the 3rd grade championship with the Kingsland Rovers in 1921, Claude continued playing for their 3rd grade team in 1922, finishing as runners-up. He was known as "C List," and his brother Percy, if involved, was referred to as "J List." Claude advanced to the Kingsland 2nd grade side in 1923 and remained there in 1924, playing on the wing.

In 1923 and 1924, Claude, known as "C List," played for the Kingsland 2nd grade team, having advanced from their 3rd grade team. During this time, he participated in a knockout competition victory against the Otahuhu Rovers and experienced two matches against Hamilton juniors with the Auckland Junior representative side on August 30 and October 4. Notably, he played on the wing in both matches, contributing to Auckland's victory in the first encounter. Additionally, he featured in a game against Devonport United 2nd grade side as a curtain-raiser for the New Zealand v England test match at Carlaw Park earlier in the season.

In 1923-1924, Claude, or "C List," played for the Kingsland 2nd grade team and participated in a knockout competition victory against the Otahuhu Rovers, as well as two matches against Hamilton juniors with the Auckland Junior representative side, scoring a try in the second Hamilton match. He also played on the wing in a curtain-raiser game against Devonport United 2nd grade side. In 1925, List made his senior debut for Kingsland in the B Division of Auckland club rugby league after the team's promotion. He also made an appearance as an Auckland representative that year.

In 1925, Claude, known as "C List," made his senior debut for Kingsland, which had been promoted to Auckland club rugby league's B Division. He was a notable selection for the Auckland team from that division, a distinction he had achieved earlier in 1928 by becoming the first New Zealand player chosen for the national side from a essentially second-tier team. List's debut match was Kingsland's first-round encounter against Northcote & Birkenhead Rangers, held on April 18 at Carlaw Park, where he scored three tries in a 21–3 victory.

In his debut match, Claude, also known as "C List," significantly contributed to Kingsland's victory by scoring three tries in their 21-3 win against Northcote & Birkenhead Rangers. He demonstrated his skill again in their third-round game against Māngere United, scoring an additional three tries in the 13-all draw. These performances showcased his talent and impact on the team's success.

During the matches with Otahuhu Rovers and Ellerslie United, Claude, or "C List," showcased his skills but couldn't secure victories. Against Otahuhu, he made multiple breaks but was stopped by strong tackling, resulting in a 16–3 loss. In their 8–5 loss to Northcote, he managed to score a try. The New Zealand Herald acknowledged his impressive individual efforts in the 9–5 loss to Ellerslie United, attributing several fine solo attempts to him. Despite not winning, his skills were still evident.

The text mentions that despite not securing victories in matches against Otahuhu Rovers and Ellerslie United, Claude, also known as "C List," demonstrated his skills with multiple breaks and a try. The New Zealand Herald recognized his individual efforts in the Ellerslie United match. Following a match with Mangere and a bye, List was chosen for the B team's three quarters in an Auckland trial match, which he helped win 5-0. The text also notes that List typically scores the most points for his team.

In the Auckland trial match, Claude, also known as "C List," significantly contributed to the B team's 5-0 victory. He made crucial plays, such as preventing a try by Roy Hardgrave and later breaking through with a run down the sideline, centering a kick that nearly resulted in a try. Additionally, List thwarted another attempt by Hardgrave. The New Zealand Herald praised List's performance, highlighting his skills as a wing-three quarter for the B team. This accolade is consistent with his reputation as a top scorer for his team.

The text mentions that Claude, referred to as "C List," excelled in the Auckland trial match, with his speed and skills helping the B team win 5-0. The New Zealand Herald and Auckland Star both praised his performance as a wing-three quarter, with the latter noting his reputation as a prolific scorer. Despite his impressive showing, List was not selected for the New Zealand side's tour to Australia, though he was chosen as a reserve for the Auckland team's match against New Zealand. He ultimately did not play and went back to his club team for three more games. This series of matches served as trials to choose the New Zealand side for the tour.

The New Zealand Herald had recognized Claude, or "C List," as a young player with exceptional form, making him a strong candidate for Auckland's Southern Tour. After another Kingsland match and a bye, he became an emergency player for Auckland's match against South Auckland. Following a loss in the Stallard Cup, List secured a spot in the Auckland touring side.

The text mentions that Claude, also known as "C List," is 22 years old and weighs 12 stone. Due to the New Zealand team being on tour with numerous Auckland players, the Auckland team is considered a B side, consisting of young members aged between 19 and 22. Their first match was against West Coast in Greymouth, where Auckland B emerged victorious with a score of 22-15. During the second half, List managed to score a try following passes from Tim Peckham, Hector Cole, and Ben Davidson, which allowed him to score in a tackle.

In the text, Claude, who goes by "C List," is a 22-year-old member of the young Auckland B team, which is currently on tour. The team, with players aged 19-22, previously won against West Coast in Greymouth. List scored a try in that match, but his performance in the subsequent match against Canterbury was less prominent, with Auckland B losing the match 6-5. Despite this, List was chosen for their final tour match against Wellington, where Auckland won by a large margin of 68-9. List contributed to the victory by scoring a try.

In the final tour match, List played a crucial role in Auckland B's 68-9 victory over Wellington by scoring a try himself and assisting Ben Davidson in another. His contribution included receiving a miskicked ball from Balks and scoring under the posts, securing a 23-4 lead for his team. Following this impressive performance, List was selected for the main Auckland side to face South Auckland on September 19, where he scored two tries in a 36-19 victory at Carlaw Park.

In his first game with the main Auckland team, List scored two tries which helped secure a 36-19 victory over South Auckland at Carlaw Park. He played on the wing alongside Ben Davidson, Leonard Riley, and Hector Cole. During the first half, List attempted to run down the line but was stopped by Smith. Later, he broke through the defense, picked up the ball, and passed it to Arthur Singe who scored a try.

In the second half of the game, List contributed to a try with Davidson by sprinting down the line and passing to him, and later scored a try himself in the corner after receiving the ball from Riley. He was also involved in another play where Dixon passed to Cole and Riley, setting up List to score near the corner again. The Auckland Star praised his performance, while the Herald noted that he started poorly but improved in the second half.

In the match against Queensland, List served as a reserve player alongside Johnston and Delgrosso, who were selected to play on the wings. Regrettably, the Auckland Province team suffered a significant loss of 54-14. During the game, Raynor, the Auckland fullback, exited the field; however, List was not chosen to replace him, and Te Whata was selected instead. The media highlighted List's improved performance in the second half of the previous game, despite his limited playing time in this match.

The Herald criticized the decision to send Te Whata, a reserve forward, to replace the injured Raynor on the wing instead of List, the designated reserve back, during the Auckland-Queensland match. The newspaper found this to be unfair to List and questioned the selectors' actions, warning that it could establish a problematic precedent. The Herald had previously noted List's improved performance in the recent game, despite his limited playing time in this match. In the 1926 season, List played 16 games for Kingsland, scoring 11 tries and making one goal.

The text discusses a player, List, who has shown strong performance in rugby games. Despite being a reserve back, he was not chosen to replace the injured Raynor, which the Herald criticized. List has been a valuable player for Auckland, scoring 7 tries in 4 games, making him a co-leading try scorer. He also played in a New Zealand trial match, scoring a try. At the beginning of the year, he was elected to the Kingsland club committee. In the first game of the season, List scored all of Kingsland's points in a close loss against Otahuhu, demonstrating his skill on the wing.

In various rugby matches, List consistently demonstrated his scoring ability, contributing to his team's offense. He scored a try against Herring and McManus' initial progress in one game, scored multiple tries in losses against Northcote and Parnell, and showcased his determination by wrestling across the line with opposing players. His standout moment came in a win over Parnell when he assisted in another try following a passing play with Herring. List's impressive performance culminated in a 4-try season tally, including a crucial score in a victory over eventual champions Northcote.

The Auckland Star praised List's strong performance in rugby matches, highlighting his notable try in a game and his contribution to a team try that involved five players. Consequently, he was selected as a reserve for a New Zealand trial match, which was a curtain-raiser for the North Island vs. South Island clash. This trial match was part of a series of games to help the New Zealand selectors choose their squad for a tour of England and Wales. List also made it to a B Team trial side that played on July 10, followed by a Probables – Possibles match.

The Auckland Star reported that List, a skilled three-quarter, would be playing in the B Team trial match, pleasing many local rugby fans who consider him one of Auckland's best. He contributed to the B Team's narrow victory by scoring a try and delivering a strong performance alongside other standout players like George Wade and Stan Prentice. This match was part of the selection process for the New Zealand team touring England and Wales.

List was initially left out of the New Zealand touring team, with the Herald suggesting his inclusion over a supposed "weak link," Jim Parkes. However, after strong performances in local matches, including a game-changing shift to center when Leonard Riley couldn't play, List secured a spot on the Auckland side that faced the New Zealand team before their departure. Auckland won the celebratory match, with List contributing a try from his center position.

In the festive match at Carlaw Park, Auckland emerged victorious with a score of 52-32 against the New Zealand team, before the latter's departure. List, who had initially been excluded from the team, contributed to Auckland's win by scoring a try and playing a crucial role in Maurice Wetherill's try. His impressive run "half the length of the field" led to Horace Dixon's try, with a crowd of 14,000 cheering them on.

The text mentions that, in the match at Carlaw Park, List, who was initially excluded from the New Zealand team, played a key part in Auckland's victory with a try, following a break by Tim Peckham and passes from Stan Prentice. List's impressive play, including a "clever swerve" to beat Craddock Dufty, was praised by the Herald, which felt he deserved to be selected for the tour. The Auckland Star criticized the New Zealand team's selection, particularly in the backs, and expressed disappointment that Ivan Littlewood, Hickey, and List were not included in the touring squad.

The initial exclusion of List from the New Zealand team proved to be ironic, as later, eight forwards refused to play due to a disagreement with coach Mair. This led to several backs, including List, having to play in the forwards. These players were subsequently banned for life. List was later chosen to train with the Auckland squad for their match against Otago on August 7 at Carlaw Park. He performed well on the wing, contributing to their 14–4 victory by scoring a try, receiving a pass from Payne and scoring in the corner. The Auckland Star's criticism of the New Zealand team's selection extended to the backs, expressing disappointment that players like Ivan Littlewood, Hickey, and List were not included in the touring squad.

In the match against Otago, List, who had previously been excluded from the New Zealand team and then banned for life after being made to play in the forwards, contributed to Auckland's victory by scoring a try with a pass from Payne, giving them a 5-2 lead. The Auckland Star praised List's handling of the slippery ball and reiterated that his skills had been proven, lamenting his absence from the New Zealand side.

After being praised for his performance in the match against Otago, List returned to his Kingsland team and scored a total of 6 tries in their victories over Otahuhu Rovers and Māngere United. His skills were once again highlighted, and as a result, he was selected for the 19-man Auckland squad to play against Canterbury. List made the final thirteen and played in the centers, contributing to Auckland's 33-15 win at Carlaw Park.

In the match against Canterbury, List played as a center and made key contributions to Auckland's victory. He assisted Wade in scoring two tries by passing and creating a gap in Canterbury's defense. Additionally, List received a pass from Prentice and scored a try himself, showcasing his acceleration and evasion skills. These actions demonstrated List's significant role in Auckland's 33-15 win.

During the Canterbury match, List's performance was exceptional as a center, contributing to Auckland's victory. He helped Wade score twice and showcased his skills by scoring a try himself. Later, List's competitive race for possession with Blazey further highlighted his abilities. The Herald praised List's performance, noting his impressive straight running, fending, and potential to become an outstanding, cooperative center three-quarter. Afterward, List resumed playing for Kingsland against Northcote.

In the B Division competition, Auckland's teams, Kingsland and Northcote, were the frontrunners with only two matches left, and Northcote held a slim 1-point lead. Northcote ultimately won, claiming the championship while Kingsland came in second. The Herald acknowledged the presence of promising talent in the B Division, specifically mentioning List's abilities from Kingsland. It was suggested that more exceptional players would emerge given the opportunity. Following this, List was selected for the Auckland team to face the South Auckland side from Waikato on October 9.

In the B Division competition, Northcote won the championship and Kingsland came in second. The Herald recognized List from Kingsland as a promising talent, who later got selected for Auckland's team against South Auckland. Auckland won the match 25-8, with List scoring three tries. His first try was unopposed, after a pass from Seagar, and his cross-kick allowed Wade to score under the posts.

During the first half of the match, List from Kingsland showcased his talent by scoring a try with a high reverse pass from Cleaver and another try after making a notable advance, followed by Seagar scoring with support from Cleaver. These successful attempts demonstrated the teamwork and skill of the players.

In the second half, List received the ball from Seagar and sprinted diagonally to score a try, impressing the Herald with his straight running and skill. Afterward, List rejoined his Kingsland team for their Stallard Cup final against Parnell on October 16, which they won with a score of 25-13, highlighting their teamwork and prowess.

In the Stallard Cup final, Kingsland, with List's assistance, defeated Parnell by a score of 25-13, showcasing their teamwork and abilities. List played excellently, setting up a try for Carter and contributing to Kingsland's victory. During the 1927 season, List played 13 games for Kingsland Rovers, scoring two tries, although there might have been more due to limited media coverage. Unfortunately, Kingsland came in second place, this time behind Ellerslie United. List's performance led to his selection for the 1927 North Island team.

In the 1927 season, Kingsland, including List, finished as runners-up to Ellerslie United. List excelled in his performance, playing 5 games for Auckland and scoring 7 tries, the most for the representative side. He also debuted for the North Island team. His season started in April, when he was chosen for Auckland's training to face the returning New Zealand team members from their England and Wales tour. Auckland won the match 24-21 in front of 14,000 spectators.

In the 1927 season, List, a Kingsland player, stood out as a center for Auckland in their match against the returning New Zealand team from their England and Wales tour. He scored a try and exhibited impressive attacking skills, with his speed and straight running frequently breaching the New Zealand defense. The Auckland Star praised his performance, noting that he outperformed B. Davidson. This was Auckland's sole representative game until late in the club season, and List featured in 13 games for Kingsland from May to September.

In the 1927 season, List played 13 games for Kingsland between May and September. He delivered noteworthy performances, including a match against Otahuhu where he showcased his skills, leading the Auckland Star to comment on his competition with Davidson for the representative team position. In another game against Mangere, his brother Francis joined him in the Kingsland team.

In the 1927 season, List had impressive showings for Kingsland, particularly in a match against Otahuhu where he was hailed as the best back by the Auckland Star. His performance included strong offensive and defensive play. The newspaper also highlighted his competition with Davidson for a representative team position. Later, in the B Division final against top-ranked Ellerslie United, List scored Kingsland's sole points, further demonstrating his value to the team.

The 1927 season saw List's exceptional performances for Kingsland, notably in the B Division final where he scored all of Kingsland's points against top-ranked Ellerslie United. The Auckland Star praised his skills, suggesting he and Littlewood of Ellerslie were strong candidates for the New Zealand team that would tour England. After a match against Parnell, List was selected for an Auckland touring squad, highlighting his value and skill as a center three-quarter.

In the 1927 season, List's impressive performances for Kingsland, particularly in the B Division final against Ellerslie United, led the Auckland Star to regard him and Littlewood as strong contenders for the New Zealand team touring England. His abilities were further recognized when he was chosen for an Auckland touring squad following a match against Parnell. The Auckland Star made a notable comparison between List and the renowned player Craddock Dufty, acknowledging their different playing styles. While Dufty was considered a better fullback, List excelled as a center three-quarter, demonstrating his skill in straight running, selflessness, and cleverness in supporting his wings.

The Christchurch Press praised Dufty's determination and ability to elude tacklers, which he demonstrated during the second half when he fielded a kick and set up List's second try. List's scoring continued in the following match at Victoria Park in Greymouth.

In their next match at Victoria Park in Greymouth, Auckland defeated the combined West Coast/Buller team by a significant margin of 42 to 15, with List scoring another try. List's performance was marked by his involvement in several tries, highlighting his scoring abilities and the weak defense of their opponents.

In the North Island vs. South Island match, List was selected to play on the wing, contributing to the North Island's victory at Carlaw Park with a 13-8 score. His impressive performance included scoring a try in the first half, after Gregory skillfully evaded multiple opponents, and almost securing another try later in the half. The Grey River Argus had previously recognized List's potential for a national squad spot.

Following this match, List participated in the Auckland side to face Buller at Carlaw Park on October 8.

In the historic match where New Zealand's backline was composed solely of Auckland players, List, playing in the centers alongside Wetherill, significantly contributed to the team's victory over England. His impactful run and well-placed kick set up a scoring opportunity for Scott. Despite England's recent success in Australia, they were unable to prevent New Zealand's upset, partly due to List's performance. Their two five-eighths system seemed to be more effective than England's single five-eighth and two centers, with Brough and Oliver.

In the New Zealand vs. England match, with a score of 4-3 in favor of New Zealand, a penalty against England close to their posts led to an unexpected play. Wetherill kicked the ball to the left flank, where List outmaneuvered English defenders, collected the ball, and scored. This play contributed to New Zealand's 11-3 lead in the second half. Wetherill's long pass to List, who then sprinted and passed to Scott, further showcased the effectiveness of New Zealand's two five-eighths system compared to England's single five-eighth and two centers. List's performance was instrumental in New Zealand's victory over England.

This success led to List's selection for the Auckland Provincial team, where he faced Mel Rosser. Despite the team's loss to England, List's performance was noted as solid in the challenging circumstances. The comparison between the two teams' center formations and List's individual success is emphasized.

The Star acknowledged that List's handling was not at his best, but he was still affected by his teammates' poor performance. List's impressive play led to his selection for the Auckland team to face England on August 11.

Early in the game, List participated in a movement initiated by Frank Delgrosso from a scrum, passing the ball to Hardgrave.

In the match against England, List was involved in a significant play where he received the ball from Frank Delgrosso and passed it to Hardgrave, resulting in a try. He also intercepted a pass during England's attack and cleared the ball. List was chosen, along with other players, for the three-quarter group in the second test, with one player to be excluded. The selected players were Len Scott, Hec Brisbane, List, and Roy Hardgrave.

In summary, List played a crucial role in the Auckland team's movement against England, intercepted a pass, and was later selected for the three-quarter group in the second test.

In the subsequent match at Caledonian Park, Dunedin, although initially considered as a potential starter, List ultimately didn't make the cut for the three-quarter group in the third test, with Brisbane, Scott, and Hardgrave being selected instead. New Zealand lost the match 13-5, and it is suspected that an injury might have been the reason for List's non-selection, as no official reason was reported.

List was likely sidelined in the third test due to an injured leg, which was evident in his play for Kingsland against Otahuhu on September 8. Despite not being in peak form, he still had moments of brilliance in the match. No official reason was given for his non-selection in the test, but his injury could have been the cause. New Zealand ultimately lost the test 13-5 without List in the three-quarter group.

List's injured leg continued to trouble him, but he showed flashes of skill in the Kingsland-Otahuhu match, which was cut short due to unruly behavior from Otahuhu players and spectators. Despite playing only half the game, List's contribution helped Kingsland maintain an 8-5 lead at halftime. Subsequently, List's improvement allowed him to make the Auckland team for their match against Otago on September 15. Auckland emerged victorious (42-22), with List playing a part in their second try.

List's leg injury didn't stop him from showcasing his abilities in the Kingsland-Otahuhu match, playing a role in Kingsland's 8-5 halftime lead. His improved performance led to his selection for Auckland's match against Otago on September 15, where he contributed to their 42-22 victory. Specifically, he assisted in Auckland's second try and was part of another scoring opportunity before the match ended. Unfortunately, his final game for Kingsland, the Stallard Cup semi-final, did not go well, with reports stating that he "failed to make an impression."

In the Kingsland-Otahuhu match, List's leg injury didn't hinder his performance, playing an important role in their halftime lead. His selection for Auckland's match against Otago resulted in a 42-22 victory, where he helped set up two tries. However, his final game for Kingsland was disappointing, as he didn't make an impact. Harsh criticism followed, noting his reliance on fending to create openings and lack of variety as a center three-quarter. Despite this, List was chosen for Auckland's match against North Auckland on October 6, where he scored the opening try and contributed to another in the second half, securing a 33-9 victory for Auckland.

In the 1929 season, List's club, Kingsland Rovers, combined with Grafton Athletic, aiming to join the first grade competition. During the Kingsland-Otahuhu match, List's leg injury didn't affect his performance, and he played a significant role in their halftime lead. However, his final game for Kingsland was disappointing. In the 1929 season, List's club, Kingsland Rovers, merged with Grafton Athletic, forming Kingsland Athletic to participate in the first grade competition. This marked List's first appearance in the first grade during his fifth year of senior rugby league. The Auckland Star newspaper mistakenly identified Grafton Athletic as the original club that had disbanded in 1922. List played 15 games for Kingsland, scoring 7 tries and 1 drop goal. Despite a disappointing final game for Kingsland, List's performance in the first grade was notable, particularly in the Kingsland-Otahuhu match, and he contributed to Auckland's victories in matches against Otago and North Auckland, scoring tries in both games and assisting in a try during the North Auckland match.

In their match against Newton, Kingsland lost the game 12-10, but List contributed by setting up a try for R. Carter and received praise for his performance. The team managed to earn their first championship point in a 18-18 draw against Marist Old Boys, with List being one of their standout backs. Despite a significant loss to Ponsonby, List was recognized for his exceptional effort and hard work.

In their loss to Ponsonby, List's hard work and efforts were still noted. He then went on to score two tries in Kingsland's first victory against Ellerslie, with a final score of 17-5. Despite limited opportunities in the Kingsland vs. City match, List managed to score a try and put up a strong defensive game, especially towards the end. However, The Herald criticized his decision to hold onto the ball instead of passing to the wing, suggesting that this may have cost Kingsland a more comfortable victory.

In the 1930 season, List, a consistent player, took part in Kingsland's games, scoring 7 tries in 14 matches, including a victory against Marist, which was initially a loss but later turned into a win due to Marist's use of an unregistered player. In 1931, due to a perceived weakness in the senior grade competition and smaller crowds, Auckland Rugby League decided to merge some teams, including Kingsland with Marist Old Boys. This merger was a response to the league's plan to reduce the number of teams in the senior grade and establish a reserve grade competition. Kingsland, fearing the loss of their players and relegation to a lower division, opted to combine forces with Marist instead. This merger ultimately impacted List's team and his opportunities, such as being selected for the New Zealand team's Australian tour.

In 1931, Auckland Rugby League combined Kingsland with Marist Old Boys to create a stronger team, as part of their plan to decrease the number of teams in the senior grade and establish a reserve competition. This merger made Marist a top contender due to their access to Kingsland's top players, which included four New Zealand representatives. During the North Island vs South Island game, List, playing as a center, scored three tries and contributed to additional tries by Meehan and Abbott. The Herald praised List's powerful and direct running style, deeming him a dangerous back, as shown when he set up both tries for Marist in their loss against Lower Waikato and later against Devonport. The 1932 season was particularly important for List, as he led Marist in tries scored and played for New Zealand in all three tests against England, making it a significant year in his career despite his injury.

In the 1932 season, List, who was the leading try-scorer for Marist, showcased his exceptional skills as a back, particularly on the wing. In the Auckland XIII's victory, List was instrumental in the team's offense, scoring three tries. The North Island emerged victorious in the match with a score of 27-18, thanks in part to List's contribution of a try. After List's notable performance in the North Island's victory, he was chosen to be part of a team of Auckland players to face England in a test match. This selection came just a few days after the inter-island match. This marks List's return to the New Zealand team for a test match against England, four years after his initial debut. The team composition includes Dick Smith and Len Scott on the wings, Albert Laing at fullback, and Hec Brisbane and Bert Cooke as five-eighths. List's opponents in the centres will be Alf Ellaby and Artie Atkinson from England.

In the test match against England, List was positioned against Alf Ellaby and Artie Atkinson in the centers. New Zealand suffered a defeat of 24 points to 9 at Carlaw Park, with a crowd of 25,000 present. Early in the game, List was obstructed by Atkinson, resulting in a free kick for New Zealand. The Star later reported that List, along with Brisbane and Cooke, demonstrated exceptional teamwork and tackling, preventing England from scoring more.

After the first test loss against England, List, despite his team's struggle, kept his spot for the upcoming second test at Monica Park in Christchurch. Before the second test, List was chosen to represent Auckland against the touring team, playing on the wing opposite Stanley Smith. Although Auckland performed well, they suffered a 19-14 defeat with List being the heaviest among the Auckland backs, weighing 12 stone, and the team's average weight being 11st 3lb. The review of the game praised the performances of Cooke, Hassan, List, and Davidson, with List scoring both of New Zealand's tries. List and ten other Auckland players then traveled to Christchurch for the second test. In the game, Watene played fullback, List was on the wing, Brisbane and Cooke were in the center positions, Davidson was on the other wing, Hassan was at five-eighth, and Abbott was at halfback. Cooke made a notable play by catching Sullivan off guard early in the match. However, New Zealand lost the game 25 to 14 before 5,000 spectators. Once again, List faced English winger Stanley Smith.

In the initial stages of the game, Cooke's quick follow-up on a New Zealand kick resulted in him tackling Sullivan, which led to a successful try by List in the corner. Later, with England ahead 10-5, Hassan received a well-timed pass from Abbott, drew Sullivan, and then passed to List, who scored another try while being tackled by Risman.

In the first part of the game, Cooke's quick response to a New Zealand kick allowed him to tackle Sullivan, resulting in List's try and a 10-10 tie after Jim Amos' conversion. Towards the end of the match, with the score at 25-14, Cooke had a near miss, attempting to assist List in scoring on the right flank.
